text:
The _experts say_ socials (LinkedIn) work for B2B companies. If so, how do you convince leadership to get on board with putting more resources into a social strategy?

*Context:* We’ve been “maintaining” socials, but it isn’t a big conversion-generator for us. I think that’s because we don’t invest in it enough. But when I say “we should lean more into socials.” They say “it doesn’t generate a lot of leads for us, so why should we?” - How would you respond?

text:
It would help to share with them examples of CEOs and executives of companies they know and look up to.

For example, if you're in SaaS, it would help sharing examples like Drift or Gong.

Seeing someone successful who's doing it already is a relatively easy way to see yourself doing it as well.

As for the question of whether the company should invest more, I guess the answer is easy for us marketers (hint: you have to be consistent), but this isn't as easy to communicate.

text:
I think drift and gong are the wrong niche to share for anyone outside of them. The value is proving there's somewhere your intended audience hangs out.

Gong is huge on LinkedIn because that's where sales folks spending their entire day.

Find the where, plan the how, show the why. 6 slides, budget request, peer reviewed, send to the big boss.

text: Provide examples and get specific on one platform vs. saying social. If you really want to invest in LinkedIn, say so, get data for specifically investing in LinkedIn, and put your resources there instead of trying to convince higher ups on social in general.

text:
Some thoughts:
1. Social doesn't directly generate leads. No one goes from seeing a social post to buying anything. Social is an education and awareness channel, that's what your goals should be.
2. Make your execs follow some people like Chris Walker, Peep Laja, folks from Gong, companies that nail organic social. This gives them an idea of how it's done and gets them hungry to be a part of it themselves.
3. Don't sell this as doing 'more social', explain to them that the vast majority (90-95%) of potential buyers is not in-market right now. The best way to still engage and capture that share of mind is through education and thought leadership on the platforms where these buyers hang out (socials).
4. Do this in a low-cost, low-tech, low-involvement way. Sit down with one or two execs per week, chat with them for an hour on things they see in the market, knowledge they feel your ICP would benefit from, trends, etc. Record, get it transcribed and create 8-12 LI posts, so they can post content for 3-4 weeks. Buy <http://shield.ai|shield.ai> to track results, and get yourself some LI premium to build a good list of people your execs can connect with.
5. If you feel you can't convince the exec team, find one exec, or one expert, or one sales person that is willing to collaborate. If you execute it right, results will start to come in a few months from now. At that point people will wake up.

elements.text: Some thoughts:
Social doesn't directly generate leads. No one goes from seeing a social post to buying anything. Social is an education and awareness channel, that's what your goals should be.

Make your execs follow some people like Chris Walker, Peep Laja, folks from Gong, companies that nail organic social. This gives them an idea of how it's done and gets them hungry to be a part of it themselves.

Don't sell this as doing 'more social', explain to them that the vast majority (90-95%) of potential buyers is not in-market right now. The best way to still engage and capture that share of mind is through education and thought leadership on the platforms where these buyers hang out (socials).

Do this in a low-cost, low-tech, low-involvement way. Sit down with one or two execs per week, chat with them for an hour on things they see in the market, knowledge they feel your ICP would benefit from, trends, etc. Record, get it transcribed and create 8-12 LI posts, so they can post content for 3-4 weeks. Buy
shield.ai
to track results, and get yourself some LI premium to build a good list of people your execs can connect with.

If you feel you can't convince the exec team, find one exec, or one expert, or one sales person that is willing to collaborate. If you execute it right, results will start to come in a few months from now. At that point people will wake up.

text: From what I have experienced, I think any type of organic content is not necessarily gonna generate you more leads in terms of selling. It is rather a 'business card' if you will so that when someone finds out about your business, they can check you up online, see if you are legit, if you have a community etc. I would definitely keep on building a social media organic presence. It just consolidates your brand more. I hope it helps!

text: Hmm, are there rules on what this assistant can and can't do? ex: can they be a writer and/or editor, or are they simply helping me to coordinate and plan projects and deal with stakeholders, as in typical assistant type work?

text: Anything goes <@U031FGLGPC5> whatever you find more relevant. Thank you!

whatever you find more relevant. Thank you!

text:
1. The assistant is a writer that's so  well-versed in the brand, the market, grammar, and content best practices that they don't need any editing.
2. The assistant is SEO savvy and not only writes for SEO but also helps with updates on the back end to keep the SEO juices flowing
3. The assistant is a great person to talk to and hang out with!

elements.text: The assistant is a writer that's so  well-versed in the brand, the market, grammar, and content best practices that they don't need any editing.
The assistant is SEO savvy and not only writes for SEO but also helps with updates on the back end to keep the SEO juices flowing
The assistant is a great person to talk to and hang out with!
Nice!

text:
Because I wished for more wishes, I have 6:
• Tight, clean copy, with just the right amount of personality/voice
• Able to find the compelling hooks when writing (especially case studies, data storytelling, etc.)
• SEO chops: Works with Surfer or equiv, relishes the challenge of reconciling great writing with great SEO
• 'Gets' the market and the funnel, can ideate & write compelling content at all funnel / life cycle stages 
• Connects the dots with actual business results (doesn't just measure success in eyeballs)
• A great culture addition to the team (hire no assholes no matter how much they check the other boxes)

elements.text: Because I wished for more wishes, I have 6:

Connects the dots with actual business results (doesn't just measure success in eyeballs)
A great culture addition to the team (hire no assholes no matter how much they check the other boxes)
